results.notes:
-Specimens observed in January
-Found fruiting on a large boulder on the edge of a forested patch of land within the Waterville Valley ski resort
-Specimens appeared shriveled when collected
-Color on the top side is golden brown to tan when dehydrated and light green to turquoise when hydrated
-Top side is smooth when dry or wet
-Bottom side is dark black and roughly textured with bristly hairs
-Specimens have a rough circular shape with an indentation near the center where the stem attaches to the boulder
-Stem connects to the boulder at one point
-Collected specimens range in diameter from 5cm-10cm

results.notes:
Sporocarps very similar/nearly identical to Hypholoma capnoides when fresh, but far thicker, meatier and more robust(e.g.) thicker stems and much larger fleshy caps.
Caps: Hygrophanous 3-10(12) cm wide, convex, rounded to plane with incurved margins (Chestnut brown and viscid when young), flattening to upturned (concave) at maturity with a reddish central disc, cream white with light brown fibrils at stream stem base, fading to dull yellow/green at maturity (often with purple spore deposit on caespitose-“under caps”). Stipes: 5-8 cm long, 1-3 cm thick. Gills: deep purple (with spore deposit), very narrowly/tightly arranged (crowded), decurrent from apex down to upper stem. Odor: sweet to farinaceous. Taste: very bitter (akin to Hypholoma fasciculare).
Substrate: Pacific Rhododendron (hence the proposed epithet, H. rhododendronicola).
Fruiting: from late summer to overwintering in mild climates; growing in caesptiose clusters from trunks or roots of the substrate; parasitic to saprophytic on both living and dead rhododendrons.
Comments: A species of significance for Western arbor/gardeners in regards as a plant pathogen. Cold weather tolerant and may over winter in mild seasons.

Site Notes from type collection: A very interesting fruiting/occurence on Pacific Rhododendron. Never seen any fungi parasitizing a Rhodie, much less a living one. The older fruiting bodies from last week that I noticed driving by are all but now wilted due to frost and thaw over the last few days, although they were very large (10-12 cm caps). You can still see sagging remnants of the large fruiting bodies in the images seen here (on side of the large Rhododendron trunk halfway up on both sides). I initially thought they were Gymnopilus (possibly in the “junonius group” or G. ventricosus) from a distance, but on inspecting them last week (w/o camera) I noted the gills were deep purple, without any visible veils and the “under fruiting”, caespitose caps were covered in deep, velvety purple spores, as is common with H. fasciculare. I returned today to see if I could gather any remnant of the fruiting only to find that smaller fruiting bodies were almost all frozen solid. I gathered what I could and dried them immediately on home drying racks and obtained a purple spore print on a glass slide for microscopy. These look very close to H. fasciculare, but I have never seen said species as large as a jumbo Gym, nor parasitizing a rhododendron. This is perhaps an unnamed or undescribed taxon that I am hoping will get sequenced and investigated further. Multiple fruiting bodies dried and stored in herbarium. Images of the smokey purple spore print on glass slide added in this observation. I will continue to monitor this spot and hope for a big flush for future harvest and analysis. Performing microscopy for spore and basidia analysis, in addition to lamellar trama, and may make a preliminary provisional name and description with my findings as a variant of H. capnoides, or perhaps as Hypholoma rhododendronicola nom. prov.

UPDATE ON 2/2/19:
Posting images of performed microscopy using a Celestron digital scope.
Microscopy: Spores ellipsoid to oval-shaped, with a central to irregular germ pore on multiple spores. Basidia on average 2- to 3-sterigmate, based on the analysis of the lamella (attaching multiple images in thumbnail bar).

Diagnostic Description:
Saprobic on Pacific Rhododendron. Macroscopically similar to Hypholoma capnoides but far larger in mature fruiting bodies(10-12cm caps). Monitored host tree through entire 2019 seasons)Fall, Spring, Summer, Winter) and host exhibited healthy habits, producing flowers in early summer and new buds in early Fall. Thus I inferred and monitored new fresh fruiting bodies the following season; producing from dead branches or stumps from prior cuts on the host tree(e.g. this species of Hypholoma is saprobic on dead wood pockets in the living host tree). Not of large concern as a threat for Pacific rhododendron populations in the PNW and elsewhere.

Distribution:
Washington State.

Habitat:
Saprobic/pathogenic to dead wood of Pacific Rhododendron.

Look Alikes:
Hypholoma capnoides macroscopically(only much larger and young caps are darker brown).

Uses:
No known uses as a medicine or textile significance at time of description.

References:
Drew T Henderson field journal/notebook. Voucher and collection(including spore printed glass slides) available for future referencing.

After monitoring new fresh fruiting bodies produced in Fall of 2019 and observing the host tree through a flowering Spring/summer, it is clear(or can definitely be inferred)that the host tree(Pacific rhododendron) is unaffected in overall health and that thus far this species of Hypholoma is not a mortal pathogen or threat for overall populations of Rhododendron in the PNW. Will continue to monitor and update field notes in following seasons.
2nd Season flush images added beginning on 11/17/2019

results.notes: Found by Jessica Rosenlieb on a group foray. Strong cucumber-like odor. Spore print faint but very light brownish where visible. All structures inamyloid. Clamp connections present in lamellar trama. Pleurocystidia abundant: tapered gloeocystidia with yellowish content in Melzer’s reagent. Most pleurocystidia found in Melzer’s reagent appeared to be somewhat collapsed. Pleurocystidia measurements: (51) 52.1 – 64.8 (70.1) × (19.1) 21.2 – 26.7 (28) µm, Q = (1.9) 2.1 – 2.9 (3.1); N = 8, Me = 59.6 × 24.6 µm; Qe = 2.5. Basidia clavate and 4-sterigmate. Basidia measurements: 21.2 – 23.47 (23.5) × 6.4 – 7 µm, Q = (3.3) 3.31 – 3.37 (3.4); N = 3, Me = 22.2 × 6.6 µm; Qe = 3.3. Spores smooth, hyaline and thick-walled. Spore measurements: (6.8) 7.5 – 9.7 (11) × (2.9) 3.2 – 3.9 (4) µm, Q = (1.9) 2.1 – 2.8 (3.3); N = 30, Me = 8.5 × 3.6 µm; Qe = 2.4

[With Renee Lebeuf and Noah Siegel]

On rhododendron leaves. Caps up to 8 mm across, stems ~1cm.

See Observation 263606 and Observation 357211, both from Big Basin.
results.location_name: Little Lake Rd., Jackson Demonstration State Forest, Mendocino Co., California, USA

results.notes:
[Found by Renee Lebeuf and Noah Siegel the day before.]

A huge number of fruitbodies, on leaves of rhododendron; only a few on redwood needles. Caps up to 10 mm, stems up to 4 cm (approximately, didn’t measure when fresh). Lamellae reach margin. No prominent basal hairs, but a circular mycelial weft present on the substrate, clearly seen in dry material. No odor.

Basidia 4-spored, ~25×6. Spores 6.2-10 × 3.1-4; Q>2. Hyphae of pileipellis with short diverticulae, pilocystidia scarce and short (~15×4), somewhat thick-walled. Cheilocystidia fusiform to cylindrical, often flexuous or genuflected; not so easily seen, perhaps because they are mixed with basidia and barely longer. Caulocystidia setifrom, abundant all over the stipe, 20-50 microns long. Clamps present in all tissues.

The description in Antonin & Noordeloos matches well, except for cheilocystidia, which they state as absent. Our basidia and spores are a bit thinner too.

results.notes:
On redwood needles.

Basidia 4-spored, 27-31 × 4.5-5.5. Spores 7-10 × 3-4. Cheilocystidia mixed with basidia and similar-looking, not sure about their real presence.

Spores are a bit smaller and basidia thinner than in descriptions. Otherwise, micro and macro features are a good match. “H. pseudocrispula is well characterized by its 4-spored, clamped basidia, ellipsoid to oblong spores, setiform caulocystidia and the absence or scarcity of pileocystidia, which, if present, are shorter than in H. cripula” [Antonin & Noordeloos].

results.notes:
Small telamonia-like mushrooms with dark rusty, somewhat russet spores/gills.
Caps: varied brown, more or less chestnut; hygrophanous and weakly striate to non-striate; cap context papery and thin, watery gray-brown
In age, caps could be near flat, but always with a smooth and usually weak umbo; sometimes wavy, upturned or splitting in age; never conical
Margins decurved when young, becoming even or wavy
Subgills present
No odor and weak mild taste
Growth with oaks, madrone, manzanita and toyon; closest to interior live oak and manzanita
Universal veil: white and scant or absent
Mycelium: white
Stipes: pale, white silky fibrillose; with rosy tint, especially at base (but whitish base in one young specimen); base either weakly clubbed or slightly tapered, but mostly cylindrical; context watery pink-beige to light brown hollow
KOH: nearly black at stipe base, dark brown on cap, and lighter brown in flesh
results.location_name: West Side Railroad Trail, Tuolumne, California, USA

results.notes:
Under live oak in mixed oak/conifer woods, somewhat of a habitat interface (open oak/manzanita woodland below on slope, more ponderosa pines above), area is below typical elevation for snow, but gets occasional snow (had not yet at this point in the winter, although did later); for what it is worth, this has been an above-average year for warmer oak woodland mushrooms in interior and southern CA.
Very generic and weak fungal scent upon collection, but becoming more noticeable and mealy when aged and dried; would not say it was ever unpleasant.
Cystidia abundant, a few with the trademark “harpoon” shape- these generally with smooth/straight sides, some of them with basal bulbs, but not all; none cylindrical
Spores: light tannish-cream (apparently this and tinted gills distinctive among melanoleuca), very elliptical and filled with warts of irregular size and density; majority 5-6 × 7-8.5, avg roughly 5.75 × 7.75 micros

results.notes: Growing among leaf litter. Potential ECM hosts noticed in the area were Quercus spp., Pinus strobus, Tsuga canadensis, Fagus grandifolia, Carpinus caroliniana and Betula alleghaniensis (probably not for this one). Locally abundant. Odor spermatic. Thick-walled pelurocystidia with obtuse and crystal-encrusted apices abundant. Pleurocystidia measurements: (40.8) 41.9 – 50.6 (57.2) × (11.5) 12.3 – 13.6 (16.1) µm, Q = (3.2) 3.3 – 3.7 (4); N = 6, Me = 46.6 × 13.2 µm; Qe = 3.5. Basidia 4-sterigmate. Basidia measurements: (22.2) 22.24 – 30.17 (30.2) × (6.7) 6.75 – 7.9 µm, Q = 2.8 – 4.4; N = 4, Me = 26.7 × 7.2 µm ; Qe = 3.7. Spores brown and with 1 large guttule. Spore measurements: (7.5) 7.9 – 9.3 (9.5) × (4) 4.4 – 5 (5.3) µm, Q = (1.6) 1.7 – 1.9 (2); N = 30, Me = 8.4 × 4.7 µm; Qe = 1.8
